VOL. XIX, NO. 27.

ALUMNI TO GATHER ON FRIDAY
Third Day of Inauguration Ceremonies
to be Given Over to Former Students.
Lacrosse Game in Afternoon.

The third day of the inauguration exercises, Saturday, the twentysecond, will be devoted entirely to
the Alumni of the University. The
Alumni celebration will commence
on Friday evening, when the
Alumni and former students will
attend a smoker at the Hopkins
Club.
On Saturday the main attraction
will be a lacrosse frame between
Hopkins, champions of the Southern Division, and either Toronto or
the winner of the Northern Division championship. In either case
a close and hard-fought battle may
be expected. Toronto has always
been able to put a fast, well-trained
team on the field, and from past
records will make Hopkins play the
game of its life in order to win.
If the game is arranged with the
Northern League champions, Baltimore can expect to see one of the
best contests ever played at Homewood; for the teams will be fighting
for the Intercollegiate championship of the United States.
On the afternoon of the game
Homewood will present a gay appearance. Several Alumni classes
will march to the grounds with
bands, and to add to the gala affair
a committee, headed by George M.
Gillet, Jr., expects to raise four
flags—the United States, the Johns
Hopkins, the Maryland and the Baltimore City flags—one at each corner of the field.
After the game the Alumni and
the former students will hold an
informal banquet on the roof garden of the Emerson. Dr. Eveleth
W. Bridgeman, the chairman of the
Banquet Committee, has arranged
a most promising program, and the
Alumni are looking forward with a
great deal of pleasure to this banquet.
All the arrangements for the A.
B. Alumni are being made by Mr.
George Dobbin Penniman, of the
Class, of '84, and Mr. Horace S.
Whitman, 'or. General Lawrason
Riggs,'02, and Mr. Leslie H. Buckler, '13, have charge of the arrangements for the M. A. Alumni. Dr.
Thomas R. Brown has charge of
the graduates of the Medical
School, and Professor J. H. Latane
is making arrangements for the entertainment of the Ph. D's.
Notices are being sent to the
Alumni, and to all those interested
in Hopkins, concerning the inauguration exercises and Alumni Day.
It is expected and earnestly hoped
that this day will prove a success.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 10, 1915.

MANY FEATURES PLANNED
FOR INAUGURATION OF
PRESIDENT GOODNOW
Distinguished Men From All Parts of United States to
Gather at Important Ceremonies—Celebration
to Extend Over Three Days.
The exercises marking the formal
inauguration of Dr. Frank J. Goodnow as president of Johns Hopkins
University, and the dedication of
the Engineering School and Gilman
Hall, will be held on Thursday,
Friday and Saturday, the twentieth,
twenty-first and twenty-second of
May. The University will be closed
on these three days, the students
taking part in the general activities.
Elaborate arrangements have
been made to make the inauguration and dedication the most notable
occasions in the history of the University. President Wilson, General
Goethals, ex-President Remsen and
Dr. Henry Carter Adams will officially take part in the exercises,
while many other prominent men
will be present among the two hundred and fifty guests who have been
especially invited.
A stand with a seating-capacity
of five thousand will be erected facing the Academic Building, for the
accommodation of students and of
the public at large. On the steps of
the building a platform will be constructed, and •here the new president of the University, the members of the Faculty and the invited
guests will be seated.
On both Thursday and Friday
there will be an academic procession, in which the Faculty, Trustees, guests and an accompanying
band of students will take part. A
corps of student ushers will be appointed, whose task it will be to
take charge of the seating of the
guests of the University.
The exercises will be opened on
Thursday at half-past four o'clock,
when the inauguration of President
Goodnow will take place. Ex-President Remsen will be the •presiding
officer of the occasion, and will present Dr. Goodnow to President R.
Brent Keyser, of the Board of
Trustees. Dr. Goodnow will be
given the University Charter and
the key of the Carroll Mansion, by
virtue of his position as guardian
and protector of the spirit and the
possessions of the University. The
new president will then make an
address, this being the only speech
to mark the ceremonies of the first
day. A reception will be held in

The complete list of notable educators and public men who will be
present at President Goodnow's inauguration has not been announced,
but it is certain that a large number
of the "big men" of the country
will be on hand. It is practically
sure that Presidents Lowell, of Harvard; Hibben, of Princeton; Hadley, of Yale; Butler, of Columbia;
and Sherman, of Cornell, will be
among the guests. Dr. Adams,
from Michigan, the first graduate
from the Johns Hopkins University,
is to be a visitor especially honored,
and will make one of the principal
addresses of the ceremonies.
Professor Ames and Dr. Magoffin have the invitations in charge,
and are constantly receiving acceptances from all over the country.
the Academic Building at • nine
o'clock on Thursday evening.
On Friday the Technical School
and Gilman Hall will be dedicated.
The formal dedication of the new
Hopkins buildings at Homewood is,
indeed, a most important occasion,
marking, as it does, the first step in
the material growth and expansion
of the University. The ceremony
will also serve as a reminder that
the dream of all who are interested
in Johns Hopkins is very nearly
realized, and that Homewood will
soon be in fact, as well as in theory,
the Hopkins campus.
President Wilson, who has accepted the invitation extended by
the committee in charge, will make
the opening address on Friday. The
interest which President Wilson
would naturally feel in Johns Hopkins as a prominent American institution of learning is of course augmented by the contributing circumstances that he is himself a J. H. U.
alumnus, and thus his presence at
the ceremonies will be peculiarly
appropriate. The Technical School
will be dedicated by Colonel Goethals, to whose engineering genius
the Panama Canal is a lasting
monument, while Dr. Henry Carter
Adams, the first Hopkins alumnus,
will dedicate Gilman Hall. The
eminent positions which Colonel
Goethals'and Dr. Adams occupy in
(Continued on page 5, col. 1)

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

PRES. WILSON TO SPEAK AT
DEDICATION OF BUILDINGS
General Goethals and Professor Adams
to Officiate at Exercises on Friday,
May 21 The President to
Make First Address.

The dedication of the new buildings at Homewood will take place
at 4.30 P. M., on Friday, May 21,
and will form one of the most impressive ceremonies which has ever
been solemnized at Hopkins.
At 4.30 an academic procession,
such as that which will be held on
the preceding day, will be formed,
and, with the students as marshals,
will proceed to the campus in front
of Gilman Hall. Here the faculty
and invited guests will be seated on
the platform which is to be erected
on the steps of the building, facing
the audience of five thousand, and
the ceremonies will begin.
The first speech will be made by
Woodrow Wilson, President of the
United States. President Wilson's
address will be a brief general address, dedicating the buildings as a
whole.
The Engineering Building will be
dedicated by General George Washington Goethals, chief of engineers
during the Spanish-American War,
member of the Board of Fortifications, chief engineer of the Panama
Canal, and first Civil Governor of
the Panama Canal Zone. General
Goethal's address will be given immediately after President Wilson's.
Gilman Hall will be dedicated by
Professor Henry Carter Adams,
Ph. D., D. D.. of the University of
Michigan. Professor Adams is the
first alumnus of the Johns Hopkins
University, having received his degree of Doctor of Philosophy in
1878. He was statistician of the
Interstate Commerce Commission
from 1887 to 1911, and in 1913
served as adviser to a commission
of the Chinese Republic on the
standardization of railroad accounts.
Professor Adams has been Professor of Political Economy and
Finance at the University of Michigan since 1887, and also holds the
position of Associate Editor of the
International Journal of Ethics.
Dr. Ralph Van Deman Magoffin
is secretary of the Committee of Arrangements for the dedication exercises, and, under his direction, all
preparations are being rapidly completed. It has been arranged that a
special committee, not yet appointed, will meet President Wilson at
the station.
The day on which the dedication
is to take place has been selected
only after a careful study of the
weather conditions of other years,
and the chances of unfavorable
weather have thus been minimized.

The memorial tablet which is to
be erected to Bob Layfield at Homewood, will not represent only the
freshman class, but the entire University.
This was agreed upon at a 1918
class meeting, held in the chapel last
Tuesday afternoon. President Sutton had been approached by the
Athletic Association in regard to
making the tablet one in whose
erection the University as a whole
would have a share, and brought
the matter up for consideration by
the class. It was unanimously
agreed that the tablet should be one
which would do all possible honor
to Layfield's memory, and therefore, that the Athletic Association
should be allowed to join the Class
of 1918 in its erection.
While definite plans have not yet
been announced, it is understood
that subscriptions for this tablet will
be accepted from all members of
the University. The freshman
class has voted to place a special
assessment upon all its members,
and so will contribute as a unit, as
will the Athletic Association.
The freshman class also decided
that, in memory of Bob Layfield,
no banquet should be held this year.
'Evans reported for the Banquet
Committee that a personal canvass
had disclosed comparatively few
men who were willing to attend a
banquet, and that most of these
were of the opinion that it should
not be held. After some discussion,
therefore, a motion was passed to
the effect that, in remembrance of
Layfield, no banquet should be held
until next year.
The freshmen are now busy preparing for contests with the sophomores, both in lacrosse and in baseball. The dates of these games
have not yet been set, but it is probable that the two classes will meet
in the latter part of this month.
Alex. Randall has been elected
captain of the freshman nine. It
was originally planned to have the
1918 baseball team meet the teams
of several local preparatory schools,
and one game has been already
scheduled, but dne to the shortness
of the time before the contest with
the sophomores, these games have
been cancelled.
Frank Sutton has been elected
manager of the freshman lacrosse
team. The candidates for the team
are practicing steadily. There are
five or six freshmen who have been
playing regularly in the 'Varsity
games, and, with a large squad of
other candidates to pick from, it is
expected that a strong team will be
turned out to meet the sophomores.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, MAY 10, 1915.
ATHLETIC ASSOCIATION MEETS

CHINESE REGARD FOR US GREAT

Nominations for Positions on Athletic
Board Made Layfield Memorial Fund
to be Raised by Entire University.

Rev. John M. Mills Says That Americans
Hold First Place in Hearts of Western
Nation China a Rising State.

A meeting of the entire Athletic
Association was held in Hopkins
Hall at i P. M. last Wednesday,
for the purpose of making nominations for positions on the Athletic
Board. President Thomas F. Troxell presided.
The first business before the
meeting was a series of announcements regarding the erection of the
proposed Layfield memorial. President Troxell stated that the provision for funds to finance the erection of the memorial is to be made
a matter in which the entire University \\*111 participate ; that all students will be expected to assist in
making up the fund. The plan
originated with the Class of 1918,
but on request of the Athletic Association the freshmen agreed to cooperate with the rest of the University in the work.
The nominations, which were
next in order, were made as follows:
For President—Messrs. M. E.
Bagley, P. Sutton, Knipp and
Primrose.
For Vice - President — Messrs.
Knipp, P. Sutton, Penniman and
M. E. Bagley.
For Corresponding Secretary—
Messrs. Penniman, Primrose, M. E.
Bagley and F. P. Hall.
For Alumni Delegate (one to be
elected), term three years—Messrs.
J. Sears, H. M. Wagner, W. C.
Schmeisser, W. Spedden Merrick
and Dr. Thomas Brown.
For Medical Delegate (one to be
elected) — Messrs. Huck, Voshell
and J. Dorsey.
For Senior Delegates (three to
be elected)—Messrs. M. E. Bagley,
Primrose, Tinges, McDowell and
H. Woodward.
For Junior Delegates (two to be
elected)—Messrs. F. Hall, Gorman,
Brooks, P. Sutton, Stuart, Binford
and Straus.
For Sophomore Delegate (one to
be elected)—Messrs. F. Sutton,
Hoffman, F. Ewing, Egerton,
Wolfe and Chalmers.

That China will have a leading
place among the great nations of
the future, was the opinion of the
Rev. John N. Mills, who lectured
last Thursday afternoon in McCoy
Hall on "The Progress and Prospects of China." He quoted the
saying of John Hay, which is written beneath his portrait in Shanghai: "Whoever understands the
Chinese has the key to the world
politics of the next five centuries."
"The Chinese,"he said,"are as well
fitted for a republic as were our ancestors in 1776, but besides internal
affairs China has had to deal with
many foreign problems. For many
centuries, however, China has been
far more democratic than those unacquainted with her history or literature could possibly believe."
Dr. Mills enumerated some of the
remarkable achievements of the
Chinese during over 37 centuries of
national existence. Five hundred
years before Gutenberg they were
printing books by means of movable types, and the Peking Gazette
has been continuously published
since 713 A. D. Though they
despised war the Chinese had powder and fire-arms as early as the
first Christian century. Town meetings of the New England character
were held at a time when our ancestors were offering up burnt sacrifices. The present backwardness
of the people is due to their religious beliefs and superstitions.
President Eliot was quoted by Dr.
Mills as saying that of all peoples
the Chinese are physically the
strongest, mentally the most intelligent, and morally the cleanest. In
commerce they cannot be surpassed
for shrewdness, yet they have permitted themselves to be checked in
their progress by a primitive belief
in spirits in air, earth and water.
This, said the lecturer, is gradually
being overcome by the work of the
schools and the Christian missions.
Sun Yat Sett, the organizer of the
revolution, is a Christian and a
large majority of the statesmen are
of this religion. In the 42,000 Government schools seventy-five per
cent. of the text-books have been
prepared by the teachers or graduates of the Christian missions, and
it is partly because so many of the
missionaries are Americans that the
United States holds first place in
the hearts of the Chinese. We must
not lose our hold upon the Chinese,
for up to this time, concluded Dr.
Mills, "New China has been made
in America."

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 10, 1915.
President Goodnow's Inauguration.

The ceremonies at which Dr.
Frank Johnson Goodnow will be inaugurated as the third president of
Johns Hopkins University, to be
held on May 20, 21 and 22, will be
the occasion for a gathering of notable men such as seldom is seen in
connection with any university exercises. During the three days
which have been set aside for the
inauguration of our President and
the dedication of the new buildings
at Homewood 'there will come to
this city as guests of the University
prominent educators and men of the
highest distinction, as well as many
alumni from all sections of the
countfy. Many promising features
have been provided for by those in
charge, and the occasion will rank
in importance high among those
events the history of which is treasured in the annals of the University.
The exercises may be said to
mark the formal beginning of a
long awaited new era in the history
of Johns Hopkins. With the inauguration of President Goodnow
the affairs of the University are
placed in the hands of a man who,
in the comparatively short space of
time in which he has been connected
with Johns Hopkins, has by virtue
of his strong personality won the
high esteem and respect of everyone at the University, and under

whose guidvice progress and prosperity seem imminent.. In the dedik.cation of the new buildings at
Homewood we see the first formal
move towards the permanent establishment of the University at its
future site. In the reunion of the
alumni opportunity is afforded for
the creation of a stronger spirit
among sons of Johns Hopkins, and
the awakening of an even greater
interest in the rapid strides which
the University is making. The
celebration,.taken as a whole, should
certainly be an occasion for great
pleasure on the part of all who are
at all interested in the progress of
the University in this important
period of expansion.
The presence of the distinguished
men who have signified their intention of attending the ceremonies
should alone prove of interest
enough to make the three days
worthy of being ranked among the
most important in the life of the
University. When such men as the
President of the United States,
General Goethals, the man who was
the prime force in the building of
the Panama Canal, and the presidents of practically all of the important institutions of learning in
the country, as well as many.alumni
who have won distinction since their
graduation, are willing to come together to join in the celebration of
an event, the fact becomes plain
that that event is of extreme importance not only to the University,
but tothose outsiders who have seen
fit to become interested in the University and its welfare.
With acceptances to invitations
coming in every day in large numbers, and with the excellent progress which ' the committees are
making in their work, nothing remains to be done except to await
the time; and when it comes, to participate whole-heartedly in the celebration, joining in with the general
feeling of good will towards our
new president, and of joy at seeing
the first strides of our expansion so
successfully completed. The undergraduate body will be assigned a
definite and active part to take in
the exercises; surely every Hopkins man will come forth with all
the enthusiasm that is in him to
help celebrate this, the most \important event at the University in
many years.
The Brady Institute.

Last week marked the formal
opening of the latest addition to the
Johns Hopkins Hospital: the James
Buchanan Brady Urological Institute. This building, which is said
to be the best equipped and most
up-to-date of its kind in this country, was made possible through the
generous gift of Mr. James Buchanan Brady, of New York, whose
name it bears. Mr. Brady consulted
with Dr. Hugh Hampton Young, of
this University, with reference to
making plans for the construction
of a building to be devoted to the
study of urology, and asked him to

name the cost of such an enterprise,
stating that he wished to give the
money to carry it through. Dr.
Young furnished plans, and estimated the cost at $600,000. This
amount Mr. Brady gave immediately and willingly.
Apart from the fact that the work
which is now in progress as a result of his generosity gives Mr.
Brady himself no mean degree of
pleasure, as was distinctly shown
by his speech at .the dedication, the
establishment of the Institute marks
the .beginning of greater advancement along lines of research in a
most important field of medical
work. The work of Dr. Hugh
Young at the Johns Hopkins Hospital has long been appreciated, and,
besides gaining for him a most enviable reputation in medical circles,
has won him scores of staunch
friends, among whom Mr. Brady is
one who has given evidence of his
friendship in this most gratifying
manner. Mr. Brady's gift has made
it possible for Dr. Young to further this work 'along lines which
would in all probability have been
well-nigh impossible of attack without the splendid equipment which
the Institute affords.
Certainly Johns Hopkins is deeply
indebted to Mr. Brady, and to show
its gratitude can only hope to offer
the work done at the Institute. Not
only has Mr. Brady increased the
scope of work at the Medical
School and Hospital, thereby giving
Johns Hopkins a distinct advantage
among medical schools, but he has
provided means for reducing suffering among patients to a minimum, and thus has established
through his splendid philanthropy
an Institute which for years to come
will undoubtedly play an important
part in the good work for which
the Johns Hopkins Hospital is
noted.
THE NEWS-LETTER takes this occasion to wish Dr. Young the best
possible success in his work as head
of the Institute, and, with the entire University, feels that time will
show Mr. Brady's gift to have been
most worthily bestowed.

Homewood, nothing will be done in
regard to Gilman Memorial, the essentially memorial feature of Gilman Hall. Funds for this memorial were secured by a bequest from
Mrs. Gilman in 1910, and, although

This Saturday the Black and
Blue team will meet the representatives of Washington and Lee University in the last contest of the
season. In making a comparison of
the two teams from last Saturday's
results it would appear that the
coming meet will be a very close
one. Hopkins has a distinct advantage in all the track events, with
the exception of the ioo-yard dash
and the 220-yard hurdles, but the
visitors are strong in the field
events, particularly the pole vault
and discus throw. However, Ben
Tappan can be counted upon to get
his share of the points for Hopkins in the field events and there is
every reason to hope that the season will close in a blaze of glory.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MAY 10, 1914.
CHAMPIONSHIP

Black and Blue Lacrosse Team Clinches
Title of Southern Division of League
By efeating Swarthmore, 6-2.

The I Uacl: and Blue lacrosse
team experienced little difficulty in
defeating Swarthmore Saturday, 6
to 2. With this victory the team
clinches the championship of the
Southern Division of the Intercollegiate Lacrosse League.
Swarthmore fought hard from
the start, but in spite of the fact
that Hopkins did not play in its
usual form the Garnet was unable
to win. Boyce scored first for Hopkins, getting one in from the edge
of the crease, and after some passing in the middle of the field Paul
Sutton passed the ball to his
brother, who shot goal easily.
Swarthmore followed with her two
shots, made lw Wetherald and Curtin.
Two more goals were made by
Hopkins before the end of the half,
Paul Sutton and Voshell sending
the ball in after some clever stick
work. The score stood at the end
oIthe half 4 to 2 in Hopkins' favor.
Swarthmore tried hard to even
up the score in the second half, but
was unat.7l,:. to score, in spite of several desperate attempts. Sutton and
Hoffman scored for Hopkins before
the final whistle, making the score
6 to 2.
With the Swarthmore game the
lacrosse season closes, with the exception of the game to be played on
Alumni Day, during the inauguraCon ceremonies. At this time Hopkins will have as its opponent either
the champions of the northern division of the league, or the strong
Toronto team. In either case an
interesting game is to be expected.

CHARLES R. SCHMIDT FOUNDS
FELLOWSHIP IN CHEMISTRY

HOPKINS DEFEATS SWARTHMORE

Charles R. Schmidt, a well-known
mechanical engineer, has founded at
Johns Hopkins a new fellowship in
chemistry for the academic year
1915-1916. Announcement of the
gift was made at the University last
week. The holder of the fellowship
wi I be expected to devote most of
bis time and energy to research
work in the department of chemistry. Mr. Schmidt has requested
that the fellowship be known as the
Use Schmidt Fellowship in Chemistry, in memory of his deceased
(laughter.
In speaking of Mr. Schmidt's
gift, Dr. H. C. Jones, professor of
physical chemistry, declared • that
such fellowships were the greatest
needs of American universities at
present.
"There is scarcely a greater need
in higher education in America than
research fellowships to be awarded
to men who have already had the
training preliminary to obtaining
the degree of doctor of philosophy.".
He said: "In a word, post doctor
of philosophy fellowships to be
awarded young menof exceptional
promise in the field of scientific research are one of the greatest needs
of our universities."
The fellowship is to be awarded
by the chemical department to one
of the advanced students in chemistry.

VOL. XIX, NO. 27.

ALUMNI TO GATHER ON FRIDAY
Third Day of Inauguration Ceremonies
to be Given Over to Former Students.
Lacrosse Game in Afternoon.

The third day of the inauguration exercises, Saturday, the twentysecond, will be devoted entirely to
the Alumni of the University. The
Alumni celebration will commence
on Friday evening, when the
Alumni and former students will
attend a smoker at the Hopkins
Club.
On Saturday the main attraction
will be a lacrosse frame between
Hopkins, champions of the Southern Division, and either Toronto or
the winner of the Northern Division championship. In either case
a close and hard-fought battle may
be expected. Toronto has always
been able to put a fast, well-trained
team on the field, and from past
records will make Hopkins play the
game of its life in order to win.
If the game is arranged with the
Northern League champions, Baltimore can expect to see one of the
best contests ever played at Homewood; for the teams will be fighting
for the Intercollegiate championship of the United States.
On the afternoon of the game
Homewood will present a gay appearance. Several Alumni classes
will march to the grounds with
bands, and to add to the gala affair
a committee, headed by George M.
Gillet, Jr., expects to raise four
flags—the United States, the Johns
Hopkins, the Maryland and the Baltimore City flags—one at each corner of the field.
After the game the Alumni and
the former students will hold an
informal banquet on the roof garden of the Emerson. Dr. Eveleth
W. Bridgeman, the chairman of the
Banquet Committee, has arranged
a most promising program, and the
Alumni are looking forward with a
great deal of pleasure to this banquet.
All the arrangements for the A.
B. Alumni are being made by Mr.
George Dobbin Penniman, of the
Class, of '84, and Mr. Horace S.
Whitman, 'or. General Lawrason
Riggs,'02, and Mr. Leslie H. Buckler, '13, have charge of the arrangements for the M. A. Alumni. Dr.
Thomas R. Brown has charge of
the graduates of the Medical
School, and Professor J. H. Latane
is making arrangements for the entertainment of the Ph. D's.
Notices are being sent to the
Alumni, and to all those interested
in Hopkins, concerning the inauguration exercises and Alumni Day.
It is expected and earnestly hoped
that this day will prove a success.

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 10, 1915.

MANY FEATURES PLANNED
FOR INAUGURATION OF
PRESIDENT GOODNOW
Distinguished Men From All Parts of United States to
Gather at Important Ceremonies—Celebration
to Extend Over Three Days.
The exercises marking the formal
inauguration of Dr. Frank J. Goodnow as president of Johns Hopkins
University, and the dedication of
the Engineering School and Gilman
Hall, will be held on Thursday,
Friday and Saturday, the twentieth,
twenty-first and twenty-second of
May. The University will be closed
on these three days, the students
taking part in the general activities.
Elaborate arrangements have
been made to make the inauguration and dedication the most notable
occasions in the history of the University. President Wilson, General
Goethals, ex-President Remsen and
Dr. Henry Carter Adams will officially take part in the exercises,
while many other prominent men
will be present among the two hundred and fifty guests who have been
especially invited.
A stand with a seating-capacity
of five thousand will be erected facing the Academic Building, for the
accommodation of students and of
the public at large. On the steps of
the building a platform will be constructed, and •here the new president of the University, the members of the Faculty and the invited
guests will be seated.
On both Thursday and Friday
there will be an academic procession, in which the Faculty, Trustees, guests and an accompanying
band of students will take part. A
corps of student ushers will be appointed, whose task it will be to
take charge of the seating of the
guests of the University.
The exercises will be opened on
Thursday at half-past four o'clock,
when the inauguration of President
Goodnow will take place. Ex-President Remsen will be the •presiding
officer of the occasion, and will present Dr. Goodnow to President R.
Brent Keyser, of the Board of
Trustees. Dr. Goodnow will be
given the University Charter and
the key of the Carroll Mansion, by
virtue of his position as guardian
and protector of the spirit and the
possessions of the University. The
new president will then make an
address, this being the only speech
to mark the ceremonies of the first
day. A reception will be held in

The complete list of notable educators and public men who will be
present at President Goodnow's inauguration has not been announced,
but it is certain that a large number
of the "big men" of the country
will be on hand. It is practically
sure that Presidents Lowell, of Harvard; Hibben, of Princeton; Hadley, of Yale; Butler, of Columbia;
and Sherman, of Cornell, will be
among the guests. Dr. Adams,
from Michigan, the first graduate
from the Johns Hopkins University,
is to be a visitor especially honored,
and will make one of the principal
addresses of the ceremonies.
Professor Ames and Dr. Magoffin have the invitations in charge,
and are constantly receiving acceptances from all over the country.
the Academic Building at • nine
o'clock on Thursday evening.
On Friday the Technical School
and Gilman Hall will be dedicated.
The formal dedication of the new
Hopkins buildings at Homewood is,
indeed, a most important occasion,
marking, as it does, the first step in
the material growth and expansion
of the University. The ceremony
will also serve as a reminder that
the dream of all who are interested
in Johns Hopkins is very nearly
realized, and that Homewood will
soon be in fact, as well as in theory,
the Hopkins campus.
President Wilson, who has accepted the invitation extended by
the committee in charge, will make
the opening address on Friday. The
interest which President Wilson
would naturally feel in Johns Hopkins as a prominent American institution of learning is of course augmented by the contributing circumstances that he is himself a J. H. U.
alumnus, and thus his presence at
the ceremonies will be peculiarly
appropriate. The Technical School
will be dedicated by Colonel Goethals, to whose engineering genius
the Panama Canal is a lasting
monument, while Dr. Henry Carter
Adams, the first Hopkins alumnus,
will dedicate Gilman Hall. The
eminent positions which Colonel
Goethals'and Dr. Adams occupy in
(Continued on page 5, col. 1)

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

PRES. WILSON TO SPEAK AT
DEDICATION OF BUILDINGS
General Goethals and Professor Adams
to Officiate at Exercises on Friday,
May 21 The President to
Make First Address.

The dedication of the new buildings at Homewood will take place
at 4.30 P. M., on Friday, May 21,
and will form one of the most impressive ceremonies which has ever
been solemnized at Hopkins.
At 4.30 an academic procession,
such as that which will be held on
the preceding day, will be formed,
and, with the students as marshals,
will proceed to the campus in front
of Gilman Hall. Here the faculty
and invited guests will be seated on
the platform which is to be erected
on the steps of the building, facing
the audience of five thousand, and
the ceremonies will begin.
The first speech will be made by
Woodrow Wilson, President of the
United States. President Wilson's
address will be a brief general address, dedicating the buildings as a
whole.
The Engineering Building will be
dedicated by General George Washington Goethals, chief of engineers
during the Spanish-American War,
member of the Board of Fortifications, chief engineer of the Panama
Canal, and first Civil Governor of
the Panama Canal Zone. General
Goethal's address will be given immediately after President Wilson's.
Gilman Hall will be dedicated by
Professor Henry Carter Adams,
Ph. D., D. D.. of the University of
Michigan. Professor Adams is the
first alumnus of the Johns Hopkins
University, having received his degree of Doctor of Philosophy in
1878. He was statistician of the
Interstate Commerce Commission
from 1887 to 1911, and in 1913
served as adviser to a commission
of the Chinese Republic on the
standardization of railroad accounts.
Professor Adams has been Professor of Political Economy and
Finance at the University of Michigan since 1887, and also holds the
position of Associate Editor of the
International Journal of Ethics.
Dr. Ralph Van Deman Magoffin
is secretary of the Committee of Arrangements for the dedication exercises, and, under his direction, all
preparations are being rapidly completed. It has been arranged that a
special committee, not yet appointed, will meet President Wilson at
the station.
The day on which the dedication
is to take place has been selected
only after a careful study of the
weather conditions of other years,
and the chances of unfavorable
weather have thus been minimized.

The memorial tablet which is to
be erected to Bob Layfield at Homewood, will not represent only the
freshman class, but the entire University.
This was agreed upon at a 1918
class meeting, held in the chapel last
Tuesday afternoon. President Sutton had been approached by the
Athletic Association in regard to
making the tablet one in whose
erection the University as a whole
would have a share, and brought
the matter up for consideration by
the class. It was unanimously
agreed that the tablet should be one
which would do all possible honor
to Layfield's memory, and therefore, that the Athletic Association
should be allowed to join the Class
of 1918 in its erection.
While definite plans have not yet
been announced, it is understood
that subscriptions for this tablet will
be accepted from all members of
the University. The freshman
class has voted to place a special
assessment upon all its members,
and so will contribute as a unit, as
will the Athletic Association.
The freshman class also decided
that, in memory of Bob Layfield,
no banquet should be held this year.
'Evans reported for the Banquet
Committee that a personal canvass
had disclosed comparatively few
men who were willing to attend a
banquet, and that most of these
were of the opinion that it should
not be held. After some discussion,
therefore, a motion was passed to
the effect that, in remembrance of
Layfield, no banquet should be held
until next year.
The freshmen are now busy preparing for contests with the sophomores, both in lacrosse and in baseball. The dates of these games
have not yet been set, but it is probable that the two classes will meet
in the latter part of this month.
Alex. Randall has been elected
captain of the freshman nine. It
was originally planned to have the
1918 baseball team meet the teams
of several local preparatory schools,
and one game has been already
scheduled, but dne to the shortness
of the time before the contest with
the sophomores, these games have
been cancelled.
Frank Sutton has been elected
manager of the freshman lacrosse
team. The candidates for the team
are practicing steadily. There are
five or six freshmen who have been
playing regularly in the 'Varsity
games, and, with a large squad of
other candidates to pick from, it is
expected that a strong team will be
turned out to meet the sophomores.

Nominations for Positions on Athletic
Board Made Layfield Memorial Fund
to be Raised by Entire University.

Rev. John M. Mills Says That Americans
Hold First Place in Hearts of Western
Nation China a Rising State.

A meeting of the entire Athletic
Association was held in Hopkins
Hall at i P. M. last Wednesday,
for the purpose of making nominations for positions on the Athletic
Board. President Thomas F. Troxell presided.
The first business before the
meeting was a series of announcements regarding the erection of the
proposed Layfield memorial. President Troxell stated that the provision for funds to finance the erection of the memorial is to be made
a matter in which the entire University \\*111 participate ; that all students will be expected to assist in
making up the fund. The plan
originated with the Class of 1918,
but on request of the Athletic Association the freshmen agreed to cooperate with the rest of the University in the work.
The nominations, which were
next in order, were made as follows:
For President—Messrs. M. E.
Bagley, P. Sutton, Knipp and
Primrose.

M. E. Bagley.

and Dr. Thomas Brown.

and J. Dorsey.

That China will have a leading
place among the great nations of
the future, was the opinion of the
Rev. John N. Mills, who lectured
last Thursday afternoon in McCoy
Hall on "The Progress and Prospects of China." He quoted the
saying of John Hay, which is written beneath his portrait in Shanghai: "Whoever understands the
Chinese has the key to the world
politics of the next five centuries."
"The Chinese,"he said,"are as well
fitted for a republic as were our ancestors in 1776, but besides internal
affairs China has had to deal with
many foreign problems. For many
centuries, however, China has been
far more democratic than those unacquainted with her history or literature could possibly believe."
Dr. Mills enumerated some of the
remarkable achievements of the
Chinese during over 37 centuries of
national existence. Five hundred
years before Gutenberg they were
printing books by means of movable types, and the Peking Gazette
has been continuously published
since 713 A. D. Though they
despised war the Chinese had powder and fire-arms as early as the
first Christian century. Town meetings of the New England character
were held at a time when our ancestors were offering up burnt sacrifices. The present backwardness
of the people is due to their religious beliefs and superstitions.
President Eliot was quoted by Dr.
Mills as saying that of all peoples
the Chinese are physically the
strongest, mentally the most intelligent, and morally the cleanest. In
commerce they cannot be surpassed
for shrewdness, yet they have permitted themselves to be checked in
their progress by a primitive belief
in spirits in air, earth and water.
This, said the lecturer, is gradually
being overcome by the work of the
schools and the Christian missions.
Sun Yat Sett, the organizer of the
revolution, is a Christian and a
large majority of the statesmen are
of this religion. In the 42,000 Government schools seventy-five per
cent. of the text-books have been
prepared by the teachers or graduates of the Christian missions, and
it is partly because so many of the
missionaries are Americans that the
United States holds first place in
the hearts of the Chinese. We must
not lose our hold upon the Chinese,
for up to this time, concluded Dr.
Mills, "New China has been made
in America."

BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 10, 1915.
President Goodnow's Inauguration.

The ceremonies at which Dr.
Frank Johnson Goodnow will be inaugurated as the third president of
Johns Hopkins University, to be
held on May 20, 21 and 22, will be
the occasion for a gathering of notable men such as seldom is seen in
connection with any university exercises. During the three days
which have been set aside for the
inauguration of our President and
the dedication of the new buildings
at Homewood 'there will come to
this city as guests of the University
prominent educators and men of the
highest distinction, as well as many
alumni from all sections of the
countfy. Many promising features
have been provided for by those in
charge, and the occasion will rank
in importance high among those
events the history of which is treasured in the annals of the University.
The exercises may be said to
mark the formal beginning of a
long awaited new era in the history
of Johns Hopkins. With the inauguration of President Goodnow
the affairs of the University are
placed in the hands of a man who,
in the comparatively short space of
time in which he has been connected
with Johns Hopkins, has by virtue
of his strong personality won the
high esteem and respect of everyone at the University, and under

whose guidvice progress and prosperity seem imminent.. In the dedik.cation of the new buildings at
Homewood we see the first formal
move towards the permanent establishment of the University at its
future site. In the reunion of the
alumni opportunity is afforded for
the creation of a stronger spirit
among sons of Johns Hopkins, and
the awakening of an even greater
interest in the rapid strides which
the University is making. The
celebration,.taken as a whole, should
certainly be an occasion for great
pleasure on the part of all who are
at all interested in the progress of
the University in this important
period of expansion.
The presence of the distinguished
men who have signified their intention of attending the ceremonies
should alone prove of interest
enough to make the three days
worthy of being ranked among the
most important in the life of the
University. When such men as the
President of the United States,
General Goethals, the man who was
the prime force in the building of
the Panama Canal, and the presidents of practically all of the important institutions of learning in
the country, as well as many.alumni
who have won distinction since their
graduation, are willing to come together to join in the celebration of
an event, the fact becomes plain
that that event is of extreme importance not only to the University,
but tothose outsiders who have seen
fit to become interested in the University and its welfare.
With acceptances to invitations
coming in every day in large numbers, and with the excellent progress which ' the committees are
making in their work, nothing remains to be done except to await
the time; and when it comes, to participate whole-heartedly in the celebration, joining in with the general
feeling of good will towards our
new president, and of joy at seeing
the first strides of our expansion so
successfully completed. The undergraduate body will be assigned a
definite and active part to take in
the exercises; surely every Hopkins man will come forth with all
the enthusiasm that is in him to
help celebrate this, the most \important event at the University in
many years.
The Brady Institute.

Last week marked the formal
opening of the latest addition to the
Johns Hopkins Hospital: the James
Buchanan Brady Urological Institute. This building, which is said
to be the best equipped and most
up-to-date of its kind in this country, was made possible through the
generous gift of Mr. James Buchanan Brady, of New York, whose
name it bears. Mr. Brady consulted
with Dr. Hugh Hampton Young, of
this University, with reference to
making plans for the construction
of a building to be devoted to the
study of urology, and asked him to

name the cost of such an enterprise,
stating that he wished to give the
money to carry it through. Dr.
Young furnished plans, and estimated the cost at $600,000. This
amount Mr. Brady gave immediately and willingly.
Apart from the fact that the work
which is now in progress as a result of his generosity gives Mr.
Brady himself no mean degree of
pleasure, as was distinctly shown
by his speech at .the dedication, the
establishment of the Institute marks
the .beginning of greater advancement along lines of research in a
most important field of medical
work. The work of Dr. Hugh
Young at the Johns Hopkins Hospital has long been appreciated, and,
besides gaining for him a most enviable reputation in medical circles,
has won him scores of staunch
friends, among whom Mr. Brady is
one who has given evidence of his
friendship in this most gratifying
manner. Mr. Brady's gift has made
it possible for Dr. Young to further this work 'along lines which
would in all probability have been
well-nigh impossible of attack without the splendid equipment which
the Institute affords.
Certainly Johns Hopkins is deeply
indebted to Mr. Brady, and to show
its gratitude can only hope to offer
the work done at the Institute. Not
only has Mr. Brady increased the
scope of work at the Medical
School and Hospital, thereby giving
Johns Hopkins a distinct advantage
among medical schools, but he has
provided means for reducing suffering among patients to a minimum, and thus has established
through his splendid philanthropy
an Institute which for years to come
will undoubtedly play an important
part in the good work for which
the Johns Hopkins Hospital is
noted.
THE NEWS-LETTER takes this occasion to wish Dr. Young the best
possible success in his work as head
of the Institute, and, with the entire University, feels that time will
show Mr. Brady's gift to have been
most worthily bestowed.

This Saturday the Black and
Blue team will meet the representatives of Washington and Lee University in the last contest of the
season. In making a comparison of
the two teams from last Saturday's
results it would appear that the
coming meet will be a very close
one. Hopkins has a distinct advantage in all the track events, with
the exception of the ioo-yard dash
and the 220-yard hurdles, but the
visitors are strong in the field
events, particularly the pole vault
and discus throw. However, Ben
Tappan can be counted upon to get
his share of the points for Hopkins in the field events and there is
every reason to hope that the season will close in a blaze of glory.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MAY 10, 1914.
CHAMPIONSHIP

Black and Blue Lacrosse Team Clinches
Title of Southern Division of League
By efeating Swarthmore, 6-2.

The I Uacl: and Blue lacrosse
team experienced little difficulty in
defeating Swarthmore Saturday, 6
to 2. With this victory the team
clinches the championship of the
Southern Division of the Intercollegiate Lacrosse League.
Swarthmore fought hard from
the start, but in spite of the fact
that Hopkins did not play in its
usual form the Garnet was unable
to win. Boyce scored first for Hopkins, getting one in from the edge
of the crease, and after some passing in the middle of the field Paul
Sutton passed the ball to his
brother, who shot goal easily.
Swarthmore followed with her two
shots, made lw Wetherald and Curtin.
Two more goals were made by
Hopkins before the end of the half,
Paul Sutton and Voshell sending
the ball in after some clever stick
work. The score stood at the end
oIthe half 4 to 2 in Hopkins' favor.
Swarthmore tried hard to even
up the score in the second half, but
was unat.7l,:. to score, in spite of several desperate attempts. Sutton and
Hoffman scored for Hopkins before
the final whistle, making the score
6 to 2.
With the Swarthmore game the
lacrosse season closes, with the exception of the game to be played on
Alumni Day, during the inauguraCon ceremonies. At this time Hopkins will have as its opponent either
the champions of the northern division of the league, or the strong
Toronto team. In either case an
interesting game is to be expected.

CHARLES R. SCHMIDT FOUNDS
FELLOWSHIP IN CHEMISTRY

HOPKINS DEFEATS SWARTHMORE

Charles R. Schmidt, a well-known
mechanical engineer, has founded at
Johns Hopkins a new fellowship in
chemistry for the academic year
1915-1916. Announcement of the
gift was made at the University last
week. The holder of the fellowship
wi I be expected to devote most of
bis time and energy to research
work in the department of chemistry. Mr. Schmidt has requested
that the fellowship be known as the
Use Schmidt Fellowship in Chemistry, in memory of his deceased
(laughter.
In speaking of Mr. Schmidt's
gift, Dr. H. C. Jones, professor of
physical chemistry, declared • that
such fellowships were the greatest
needs of American universities at
present.
"There is scarcely a greater need
in higher education in America than
research fellowships to be awarded
to men who have already had the
training preliminary to obtaining
the degree of doctor of philosophy.".
He said: "In a word, post doctor
of philosophy fellowships to be
awarded young menof exceptional
promise in the field of scientific research are one of the greatest needs
of our universities."
The fellowship is to be awarded
by the chemical department to one
of the advanced students in chemistry.

The University of Michigan athletes have placed the ban on the use
of tobacco at mass-meetings held in
the honor of varsity teams. They
are also working to abolish all betting on games, drinking after victories and the use of profane language by members of the team. The
movement was entirely voluntary
on the part of the athletes.
